{"comments": {"id": 23553, "count": 597, "talk_id": 1880}, "threadId": 23553, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "1880", "description": "The one thing all humans have in common is that each of us wants to be happy, says Brother David Steindl-Rast, a monk and interfaith scholar. And happiness, he suggests, is born from gratitude. An inspiring lesson in slowing down, looking where you're going, and above all, being grateful.", "event": "TEDGlobal 2013", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "David Steindl-Rast: Want to be happy? Be grateful", "slug": "david_steindl_rast_want_to_be_happy_be_grateful", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "1617", "slug": "br_david_steindl_rast", "is_published": true, "firstname": "David", "lastname": "Steindl-Rast", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Monk", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/9bd1ea94699473f4fea2435f422e5e4156f52e59_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "There are many things for which we cannot be grateful, but there is no moment for which we cannot be grateful, because in every moment, even difficult ones, we have the opportunity to do something.", "whotheyare": "Brother David Steindl-Rast, a Benedictine monk, meditates and writes on \"the gentle power\" of gratefulness.", "whylisten": "

Many first met Brother David Steindl-Rast through a viral video called "Nature. Beauty. Gratitude," where Louie Schwartzberg's footage of time-lapse flowers in bloom is narrated by Brother David's moving words asking us to simply be ... grateful. Since 1953, Brother David has been a monk of Mount Saviour Benedictine monastery in New York, dividing his time between hermitic contemplation, writing and lecturing. He's the cofounder of gratefulness.org, supporting ANG*L (A Network for Grateful Living).

He was one of the first Roman Catholics to participate in Buddhist-Christian dialogue, and is the author of The Ground We Share, a text on Buddhist and Christian practice, written with Robert Aitken Roshi. His other books include Gratefulness, the Heart of Prayer and Deeper Than Words. His most recent book is 99 Blessings, a series of prayers for the general reader -- whether people of faith, agnostics, or uncertain.

cannot be grateful, because in every moment, even difficult ones, we have the opportunity to do something.", "whotheyare": "Brother David Steindl-Rast, a Benedictine monk, meditates and writes on \"the gentle power\" of gratefulness.", "whylisten": "

Many first met Brother David Steindl-Rast through a viral video called "Nature. Beauty. Gratitude," where Louie Schwartzberg's footage of time-lapse flowers in bloom is narrated by Brother David's moving words asking us to simply be ... grateful. Since 1953, Brother David has been a monk of Mount Saviour Benedictine monastery in New York, dividing his time between hermitic contemplation, writing and lecturing. He's the cofounder of gratefulness.org, supporting ANG*L (A Network for Grateful Living).

He was one of the first Roman Catholics to participate in Buddhist-Christian dialogue, and is the author of The Ground We Share, a text on Buddhist and Christian practice, written with Robert Aitken Roshi. His other books include Gratefulness, the Heart of Prayer and Deeper Than Words. His most recent book is 99 Blessings, a series of prayers for the general reader -- whether people of faith, agnostics, or uncertain.

"}], "speaker_name": "David Steindl-Rast", "tags": ["culture", "faith", "happiness", "mindfulness"], "title": "Want to be happy? Be grateful", "video_type": {"id": "1", "name": "TED Stage Talk"}, "viewed_count": 7016544}]}
author: David_Steindl-Rast;
title: Want to be happy? Be grateful
